course.subject: COMP
course.name: Deep Learning in Computer Vision
course.description: Deep learning has significantly advanced the performance of computer vision system from object recognition to image processing. This course covers the basics and various applications of deep learning in computer vision. Students will study the details of convolutional neural networks as well as recurrent neural networks and train deep networks with end-to-end optimization, and learn deep learning based approaches for both high-level and low-level computer vision tasks such as image recognition and image enhancement. Through programming projects, students will implement, train, and test deep neural networks on cutting-edge computer vision research. Students would be required to study or do research in a final course project related to deep learning and computer vision and present their work by the end of the course.
course.prerequisites: (COMP 2011 OR COMP 2012 OR COMP 2012H) AND (MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121 OR MATH 2350)

reviews.author: Threch
reviews.title: Advanced Deep Learning course
reviews.comment_content:
A large part of content comes from Stanford's CS231n and Michigan's EECS 498-007 / 598-005. Professor will also share his research related to Computer Vision, which is impressive and inspiring.

Content:
1. Image classification
2. Loss function and optimization
3. Introduction to neural networks
4. Convolutional neural networks (CNN)
5. Training neural networks
6. Deep learning hardware and software
7. CNN architectures
8. Recurrent neural networks (RNN)
9. Attention and Transformers
10. Detection and segmentation
11. Generative models
12. Visualizing and understanding
13. Video Models
14. Self-supervised Learning
15. Deep 3D Vision
16. Learning-based Sensing Technology
17. Invertibility in Image Processing and Restoration
18. Other Research Review...

Very fruitful content and advanced knowledge involved.

Coursework:
1. Programming Assignments x3, each 12%
2. Midterm Exam, 35%
3. Project: 29%
- Proposal: 2%
- Milestone: 3%
- Presentation: 4%
- Report: 20%

Having late policy which allows you to share 8 late days for assignment and each up to 4 days. For group project, you can have a group up to 3 people and share another 8 late days in total.
reviews.comment_teaching:
During the lectures, cqf mainly just reads the slides and add some explanations to some complicated concepts. However, his voice is too soft and I can even hear better in zoom rather than sitting in the classroom, which is ironic. Also, his delivery skill is not good such that it is quite difficult to understand what he wants to present even the concepts or contents are easy.

There are some lecture videos on Youtube of CS231n. You may want to watch those videos to understand the major content of this course, which is recommended. The lecture slides are also mainly come from CS231n.

There are Lab session for helping students to understand the coding in deep learning and help them for finishing the assignments. You can watch the lab videos if you want on the course website and visit the related tutorials posted, although those hyperlinks are mostly outdated or 404 not found. D:

Assignments are copied from CS231n, you can find many useful reference on web. However, the assignments are using outdated version of Tensorflow and PyTorch (Tensorflow v1 D:). You may need to set up your own environment and even modify the code of utilities provided.

The research of cqf is inspiring and impressive, which may be favorable for those passionate in Computer Vision.
reviews.comment_grading:
Based on curve, generally the grading is good for me.

My score:
Assignment: Full for all (mean for each assignment is around 90-95 / 100)
Midterm: 74/100, mean 70.33
Project: Full for Proposal, Milestone and presentation (whether many students full for these parts also). 93/100 for final report  (mean is around 92.x)

Final grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Average or High.

For those who are new to deep learning, you may need time to follow the contents and understand it. If you have the relevant knowledge on it, then the workload should not be high for you.

Assignment is not very difficult. You can refer to Lab assignment help session or online resources for helping you to finish it.

Midterm is quite difficult to me as I don't have any knowledge in machine learning before. It is open book so that you can view your notes on your notebook, which saves your time from reciting those concepts and architectures.

Project workload is varied and depended. You can choose any  topic you want related to Computer Vision. The most time-consuming part is the final report. It needs to be written in CVPR style for 6-8 pages.

reviews.author: J Yang
reviews.title: In-depth DL course
reviews.comment_content:
A combination of Stanford's CS231n and Michigan's EECS498-007. The professor also shares some of his research results regarding computer vision.

Youtube has a collection of Stanford CS231n offered in Spring 2017, which I highly recommend watching while studying this course. The syllabus is basically the same.

Three Python programming assignments. Can be easily sourced from various Github pages. Coding from scratch may take days and requires proficiency in NumPy and PyTorch. Luckily you can learn these packages when doing homework with these references.

The midterm is conventional. No coding and mostly chain rule. I attach one of the past papers to give you an idea.

The project requires 1-3 people per group. It could be a realization of a conference paper, some experiments on a new dataset, etc. etc. At last, you need to write a research paper of 6-8 pages in CVPR style.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen mostly reads the slides. But since the slides are of high quality, I think it's not a bit of a problem.

There is a lab session. TAs will go through homework and introduce some usage of PyTorch of Tensorflow. Totally optional.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
Assignments: 3 * 12% = 36%
Midterm: 35%
Project:
--Proposal: 2%
--Milestone: 3%
--Presentation: 4%
--Report: 20%

There is a late policy in this course. Assignments share a total of 8 late days with up to 4 late days per assignment. Project share a total of 8 total days as well.

Curve grading but fair. Here are some statistics of me and my friends:
96/100: A+
94/100: A
92/100: A-
The bins seem tight, but since everyone is doing great in assignments and projects, the only difference lies in midterm. Get prepared!
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload.

Each assignment takes less than a week to finish. However, more time is needed if no prior Numpy or Anaconda experience.

Midterm takes about a weekend to review.

Project workload largely depends on the topic your group chooses. I would say it's time-consuming to write 6-8 pages in CVPR style. Just go check one of the CVPR papers to get a grip of what that means.

I guess other students would also make their best endeavours to get a high score in the final report to make up scores lost in midterm (if any), but it turned out that the scores of all assignments related to the project are not differentiated. This is really frustrating.☹️

reviews.author: ccccdd
reviews.comment_content:
大部分內容同 stanford 嘅 cs231n 同埋 michgen 嘅 Deep Learning for Computer Vision 非常相似。呢兩科網上都有片睇。十分推薦想讀呢科嘅人去睇下自己仲唔仲意，或者當預習。最尾professor會介紹下佢自己個研究。所以內容會比果兩科多啲同新啲。

功課方面一共三份同 cs231n 差唔多嘅功課，網上好多 source。最後一份 project，最多3人一組。final report係論文格式，6-8 page，當鍛煉下寫paper。

一個 mid term 冇 final。多數學嘢，冇coding。mid term嘅source就好難搵，睇題目非常基礎，比如問下RNN入面gradient點計出來，計下CNN嘅output size。mid term算難。
reviews.comment_teaching: zoom上課就有啲悶。呢幾年網上嘅ML或者tensorflow嘅course都多，推薦唔明嘅時候搵搵呢啲。或者問下TA。
reviews.comment_grading: 整科 weighted total 有 91+ 有A。我估mid term同project係容易拉大差距嘅地方，整體grade算好。
reviews.comment_workload:
三份功課每份內容都多，就算睇source都要一段時間先睇得明，精通python有優勢。

三份功課共享8日delay 但每樣最多4日，通常後兩個會用到幾日。project嘅 proposal, milestone, final report都一樣8日delay，我就用晒去 milestone 同 final report。
